author: janekholsten
title: Cardano Vision Website Germany
description:
The germans are very sceptic on the entire cryptospace.
Many barely know that bitcoin exists and think it exists for criminal use only.

assessments.note: It's a good proposal to gather new people who are interested and will contribute to Cardano community. And yes, reaching out more young people to understand what Cardano & Project Catalyst would be one of the option to grow the community.

The idea behind this proposal is essentially strong, but feels like it hasn't been fleshed out and streamlined sufficiently - in my view. The name of the challenge under which it was filed is "F4: Proposer Outreach" - hence, to me, the main weakness of the proposal can be summed up by the fact that it does not really mention or dwell on the "proposer".
The specific type of proposer who is the direct target of this challenge are "entrepreneurs from outside the Cardano ecosystem". Not only the general German population, or the student population. Yes, of course, proposers are to be found among them, but a more guided focus on Proposer Outreach would have been good, in my view.
Popularizing Cardano is a noble goal, but a bit more focus on attracting enrepreneurs specifically might have improved this proposal further and strengthened its chances. I would not be discouraged if this proposal does not pass (it may!). If it is not selected now, flesh it out with more details and with the "uncaptured proposer" in mind.
As one of the most advanced economies in the world, being able to spread the Cardano message across Germany would very likely have positive impact to the Cardano ecosystem.

The focus of this proposal is to educate students about Cardano and Catalyst. So it can be seen as within the challenge setting. Explaining the potential of Cardano (here for the german audience) can be an important contribution to the community.

The proposer is aiming to create an online information hub with additional marketing to target German students in order to educate them on Cardano. This will not include anyone outside of German community who arent students. In addition, it appears the project will require more time to gain traction, and will miss on next two funds, therefore 2 stars.

It's a great challenge and the proposed solution appears to be a great start to develop a platform for Germans interested in learning about the project can promote the efforts of the community. Focusing on student is a great way to start as through intellectual initiatives they can find the value in understanding the technologies and could form teams to develop more presentations and ideas to be on the spotlight.

Whilst the proposal has merit and benefit to the targeted community there is an issue about longevity and the maintenance of the solution past the graduation of any students involved. However, the motivation of the students is a good counter to the lack of experience. Provisioning of information to a language other than English is required for Cardano to achieve its goals of being a global protocol.

With that budget and the target market is student/young people who use website & mobile phone, this proposal could be implemented successfully. It would be great if more German universities or students now about Cardano & Project Catalyst. And how this will change the community in Germany in the future.

This proposal seems to benefit from the enthusiasm of the proposer and the declared links to students studying entrepreneurship. However, while the proposal may be implemented successfully -  a website and the hosting of events "that make Cardanos vision visible for all Germans" - it is also a question whether building a website can "make Cardanos vision visible for all Germans" - among other initiatives. A build it, they will come model my not work the best in terms of Proposer Outreach - it might, but the proposer should make the case for hs idea. Also, education about Catalyst is only one aspect of Proposer Outreach. The company involved has not yet ben founded, the proposer mentions that for some tasks he "can share no references yet" - in responses to comments. Some additional metrics or ideas on how to assess whether the proposed plan would work - would have been welcome (Did we get proposals from outside our ecosystem through our initiative - and how to we know?)

The plan is vaguely described and it's not clear what experience the proposer and his team have regarding Cardano, or even technical experience on the development of websites, videos and effective advertising.

It is a team of students and they describe themselves as not experienced but as motivated.
They idea is to create content (website, explain videos, webinars) in german but they could not provide any references yet. With the information given I have to disagree, that there is a high probability that the proposal will be implemented successfully.

The proposer appears to be working with a team of students with a similar vision who are eager to break the stereotypes of crypto within their circle of influence. Given low start up costs, this project has potential to materialize and become successful.

The presence of abundance in the proposer circle funding could bring together an implementation strategy that brings confidence to the community. The breakdown of the funds distributed across the stages appear reasonable. The proposer has revealed experience in programming and the team and course explored seams to have the drive to do so.

The proposal should be commended for itemising the budget but it fails short on providing information on the timelines, development milestones and content of the website. As a student project within the field of study, the lack of experience in implementing such a resource is not in question. However to gain a higher rating, additional information is needed including the number of participants and the respective skillset of the team members.

Yes, the proposal provides quite sufficient information on how feasible it is. It would be more easier for the voter, if the proposer added what is the KPI of the project & how many events they want to hold within that budget.
I think that this proposal lacks  sufficient information to demonstrate how effectively it addresses the challenge. It seems that it could benefit from additional detail and milestones.

There are no roadmaps or milestones presented, no description on what content will be presented in the websites and videos. There are no performance or success indicators (i.e. how many students to you intend to reach with this proposal)

The team does not provide any metrics to measure progress and success of their approach. How many students do they want to reach? How many new proposal should be submitted? What is the time horizon of the project? What can the community expect as a result? The proposal does not appear to be mature yet.

The proposer provides sufficient information breaking down their expenditure of funds requested. The proposal is lacking an approximate timeline before a certain result is achieved, and does not include any KPIs to monitor the success.

More information on what subjects will the proposal cover and how many universities and social circles will the materials produced by the proposal will be implemented. More clarity expanding on the metrics surrounding the reach expected to be delivered from the project and other areas outside institutionalized circles and unexplored potentials would be interesting.

There is not a lot of detail provided to enable proper tracking of the developments and its results. Additional information in terms of timelines, skillsets, metrics (e.g. click rate on website) and most importantly content is required. I don't want to fully discourage this proposal as it has the foundations of being a very much needed resource to the approximately 130million German-speakers in the world. But its off to a good start. I hope this is expanded further for serious consideration.

solution:
We create a website and host events that makes Cardanos vision visible for all germans.
-> Educate about Catalyst and get students on board.
experience:
I have background in programming and motivated studs.
We are a group of students that study entrepreneurship and founded a company to do so.
